content.raw: On [this_branch](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branch/graphs_part4_shane) this find is eliminated and `PERFORMANCE_graph` runs the old code (before eliminating the other find) with the new. It's a significant speed up (About 1/3rd the time).
content.html: On this_branch this find is eliminated and PERFORMANCE_graph runs the old code (before eliminating the other find) with the new. It's a significant speed up (About 1/3rd the time).

content.raw: It definitely reduces the worst case complexity. The other `std::find` can be eliminated too.
content.html: It definitely reduces the worst case complexity. The other std::find can be eliminated too.

content.raw: Can use the same trick of storing visited to eliminate this `std::find` too
content.html: Can use the same trick of storing visited to eliminate this std::find too

Can eliminate this find too

if (visitorGraph.VertexFromId(vId).Data())
  continue;

content.raw: Thanks for the suggestion. I'll note this idea for the next round of improvements if you don't mind.
content.html: Thanks for the suggestion. I'll note this idea for the next round of improvements if you don't mind.

content.raw: There's a way but in requires to create a new graph based on the one passed in as a parameter. I implemented `BreadFirstSort()` with this strategy. Not sure if it's worth the extra copy. 760b3bf. Let me know what you think.
content.html: There's a way but in requires to create a new graph based on the one passed in as a parameter. I implemented BreadFirstSort() with this strategy. Not sure if it's worth the extra copy. 760b3bf. Let me know what you think.

content.raw: Is there a way to store data on the vertex itself? If the algorithm could store data on the vertex it would eliminate this `O(V)` find.
content.html: Is there a way to store data on the vertex itself? If the algorithm could store data on the vertex it would eliminate this O(V) find.

else
  continue;

content.html:

content.raw:
```
else
  continue;
```

If a vertex has already been visited there's no need to check its edges again.
content.html:
else
  continue;

If a vertex has already been visited there's no need to check its edges again.

content.raw: This is more of a cool idea rather than a comment, but a `BreadthFirstIterator` would allow getting the same info as `BreadthFirstSort` with the advantage of being able to bail out early if only a subset of the graph is needed.
content.html: This is more of a cool idea rather than a comment, but a BreadthFirstIterator would allow getting the same info as BreadthFirstSort with the advantage of being able to bail out early if only a subset of the graph is needed.

content.raw: sounds good
content.html: sounds good

content.raw: Function removed in d4db96f (see my other comment for the explanation).
content.html: Function removed in d4db96f (see my other comment for the explanation).

content.raw: Function removed in d4db96f (see my other comment for the explanation).
content.html: Function removed in d4db96f (see my other comment for the explanation).

content.raw: Actually, I have removed the breadth first and depth first search functions. I'm not entirely convinced of their utility. `VertexFromId()` should be more efficient and not sure why you should care about different implementations of the search function. I can be convinced otherwise but I removed them in d4db96f.
content.html: Actually, I have removed the breadth first and depth first search functions. I'm not entirely convinced of their utility. VertexFromId() should be more efficient and not sure why you should care about different implementations of the search function. I can be convinced otherwise but I removed them in d4db96f.

content.raw: Should this function return some kind of reference to the the vertex that was found, or null/empty when not found?
content.html: Should this function return some kind of reference to the the vertex that was found, or null/empty when not found?

content.raw: You could call this function a breadth first search.
content.html: You could call this function a breadth first search.

content.raw: This is more like a breadth first sort, since this function sorts the vertices in a breadth first manner.
content.html: This is more like a breadth first sort, since this function sorts the vertices in a breadth first manner.

content.raw: Suggestion: add a loop and a detached vertex
content.html: Suggestion: add a loop and a detached vertex

content.raw: I see the optimization but the only point of this algorithm is to return the list of vertices in this particular way (breadth first), right?
content.html: I see the optimization but the only point of this algorithm is to return the list of vertices in this particular way (breadth first), right?

content.raw:
minor optimization, use `std::set` for `visited`? you can avoid the extra look up here and provide a faster look up below. 

This changes the return type though so it depends on whether the order of elements `visited` is important or not as `std::set` doesn't preserve the order.
content.html:
minor optimization, use std::set for visited? you can avoid the extra look up here and provide a faster look up below.

This changes the return type though so it depends on whether the order of elements visited is important or not as std::set doesn't preserve the order.
